qas.question: Which ocean name is translated to mean "all the sea?"
What process obscures information aboutt he ocean during the Triassic period from inspection?
What was occurring to Pangaea in the late Triassic?
Which sediements in the US are an indication of the break up of Pangaea?
What type of terrestrial animals are found from the Triassic period?
What can still be found in the deep-sea from the Trissic?
What continent ripped apart during the Triassic?

plausible_answers.text: The first nonmarine sediments in the rift

qas.question: What indicates when New Jersy seperated from Rhode Island?
What stratigraphy is mostly based on non-saline organisms?

context: The remainder was the world-ocean known as <a0_0>Panthalassa<a0_0/> ("all the sea"). All the deep-ocean <b5_0>sediments<b5_0/> laid down during the Triassic have disappeared through <a1_0>subduction of oceanic plates<a1_0/>; thus, very little is known of the Triassic open ocean. The supercontinent <a2_0><b6_0>Pangaea<b6_0/> was rifting<a2_0/> during the Triassic—especially late in the period—but had not yet separated. <b7_0>The first nonmarine sediments in the rift<b7_0/> that marks the initial break-up of Pangea—which separated New Jersey from Morocco—are of Late Triassic age; in the U.S., these thick sediments comprise the <a3_0>Newark Supergroup<a3_0/>. Because of the limited shoreline of one super-continental mass, Triassic marine deposits are globally relatively rare; despite their prominence in Western Europe, where the Triassic was first studied. In North America, for example, marine deposits are limited to a few exposures in the west. Thus <b8_0>Triassic<b8_0/> stratigraphy is mostly based on organisms living in lagoons and hypersaline environments, such as Estheria crustaceans and <a4_0>terrestrial vertebrates<a4_0/>.
